entry.title: Re: Pharmaceutical Industry best practices - calibrations
entry.content: Calibration is a key best practice in the pharmaceutical industry because it ensures equipment gives accurate and reliable results. Proper calibration helps maintain product quality, patient safety, and compliance with GMP guidelines. Best practices include having a documented calibration schedule, using standards traceable to recognized authorities, and keeping clear, up-to-date records. If any instrument is found out of tolerance, its impact on product quality should be assessed and corrected immediately. Quality-driven companies like JM Laboratories follow systematic calibration procedures and regular reviews to ensure consistent performance of instruments and smooth regulatory inspections.

entry.title: Improving User Experience in SAP FSM by Customizing the Home Screen Welcome Text
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Field Service Management displays a default welcome message on the home (shell) screen after login, as highlighted below.

In some projects, there is a requirement to customize this message based on company branding or to clearly differentiate between system environments.

Requirement

The requirement was to replace the standard welcome text with a custom message in order to:

  • Improve user experience
  • Clearly identify the tenant or environment (QA / PROD)

Solution Overview

SAP FSM provides a standard configuration option to control the home screen (shell) content.
Using Label Translations, the default welcome text can be modified without any custom development or extensions.

Process for Customizing the Welcome Text

  1. Log in as Admin and select the company for which you want to change the home screen welcome text.
  2. After selecting the company, scroll down to the Translations section and click on it.

       3. Click on Label Translations.

      4. Click on the Create button to create a new value translation.

     5. Maintain the Following Details

  •  Clients: ALL
  •  Language: Choose your preferred language (for example, English)
  •  Key: SHELL_WELCOME_TO_SAP_FIELD_SERVICE_MANAGEMENT (For the home screen welcome text, this key must be used.)
  • Value: Enter the text that you want to display on the SAP FSM home screen. In my case, I used the following value: (Welcome to SAP FSM ‚Äì Production Environment ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê)

Result

After saving the translation and refreshing the session (or re-login), the updated welcome text is displayed on the SAP FSM home screen.

Conclusion

Customizing the SAP FSM home screen welcome text using Label Translations is a simple yet effective configuration that improves usability and environment clarity. Since it is configuration-based, it can be easily maintained without additional development effort.

entry.title: Migration of XSA between OS with different CPU architecture
entry.content:
You are planning to migrate your SAP system with integrated XSA from one OS to another and both have different architecture.

Note: I am writing this blog in reference to HTC migration (Where the source was running on Linux PowerPC ppc641e 64 bit (Little Endian) and target was running on Linux x86-64)

Pre-req 

On target you have installed XSA with version same or higher as comparision to source.

In the start you have to follow normal process 

Disable XSA on target  (  XSA disable)

Run the backup XSA command on source (XSA backup-fss)

Once above backup completed start the replication and perform take over.

After takeover restore the XSA on target and then enable XSA. ( XSA select-xsa-runtime-db <Tenant DB> )

Once the XSA enabled you will see that even though all the XSA services are running successfully but instances of the apps in SAP space are not running. ( Even though if you try restaging the apps it will not work)

Now check the runtimes here you will find that the some of the runtimes are CPU architecture dependent and will be based on the source. But as on the target we have different architecture the runtimes from the source will not work and therefor the apps are not starting.

Don't worry we have solution for this 

First take a note of all the runtimes those are arcitecture dependent. Below is the example you will get it when you run "xs runtimes" (Better to have scrrenshots of XS runtimes before moving ahead as we will need this later for reference)

node14.21 14.21.3.0    48(ID)      true     true     Node.js 14.21.3 for Linux x86-64 (architecture dependent)    10 (Bound apps)

Take note of ID, Bound apps with version of the node as you have to install the same version later or the bounded apps will not start.

Now with the help of runtime ID's one by one delete all the source dependent runtimes.

xs delete-runtime -f -i <ID> (make sure you are only deleting the platform dependent runtimes don't delete anything else)

Once all the runtimes are deleted use hdblcm and the same XSA package (You used to install the XSA) and update the XSA related components.

After the component update is finished again check the "xs runtimes" and compare it with the older runtimes screenshots check if all the runtimes with bounded apps came or not.

In our case customer was having older versions of node on source and have bounded apps with it.

After update components we only got node version 16 and 18. 

But customer have some apps bounded to node version 14, 12 and 10. 

So to install the older runtimes we downloaded previous XSA SAR files from SAP for me.

And then extracted the older node version from there. 

This is not a recommeded approch but as we were in middle of the migration we don't have any option left. And also customer confirmed that they will update the XSA components to latest version after the migration.

We followed below approch to install the older node version.

  1. download XSA 1.0155 installation SAR (EXTAPPSER00P_155-70001316.SAR)
  2. extract it to some temporary directory ("sapcar -xvf EXTAPPSER00P_155-70001316.SAR)
  3. extract the contained file "packages/INITIAL_CONTENT.TGZ ("tar xvfz INITIAL_CONTENT.TGZ")
  4. in the contained installdata/runtimes directory, you will find node-12.x, which you can install with
    xs create-runtime -p installdata/runtimes/node-12.x (first perform "xs-admin-login" and then create the runtime) 

    xs create-runtime -p $XSPATH/node_14 (This is how we installed node 14)

    Once you have created all the required runtimes perform the restage of the apps using below command.

    xs runtimes (It will show that you have got the runtimes dependent on the target architecture)

    XSA restage-at-startup

    XSA restart 

    Once the restart is completed you will see that the standard apps in SPACE SAP are running fine.

    If any apps are still not running than try the restage for that individual app and then restart the app.

    xs restage <APP name>

    xs restart <APP name>

    once this is completed run all the XSA post migration related commands.

entry.title: Re: The behavior of dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas
entry.content:
Hi @N1kh1l 

In Case 1, your point that "the IF condition is redundant" is correct. The AF script produces the same result even without the IF condition.

The reason for writing this article is that, in many user cases, although the expected results correspond to Case 3 and Case 4, the AF scripts are often written as Case 1 and Case 2. This article was written to help prevent that. 

Before the "== "and "!==" operators were delivered, adding FOREACH [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] to the Case 1 script was the workaround solution to achieve the result of Case 3.

MEMBERSET [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/Start] TO [d/Version].[p/End]
MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200", "CC300")

FOREACH [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]
	IF [d/Company_Code] = [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
		DELETE()
	ENDIF
ENDFOR

Regards,

Moonjun

entry.title: How to Export All Users (with Origins) from All SAP BTP Subaccounts via CLI Automation
entry.content:
Introduction

If you manage a large SAP BTP Global Account, you may find it challenging to export a full user inventory‚Äîespecially when your environment is segmented into multiple subaccounts and utilizes various identity provider origins (multiple trusts). The SAP BTP Cockpit does not offer a single "Export All Users" button at the global account level.

This blog demonstrates how to efficiently extract all users and their identity origins across all BTP subaccounts using the SAP BTP Command Line Interface (btp CLI) and PowerShell scripting.

Prerequisites

  • btp CLI: Ensure you have downloaded and installed `btp.exe` (the SAP BTP CLI). [Download Link]
  • Login Required: Log in to your SAP BTP Global Account using the CLI: btp login
  • Open a CMD window and enter:

  • Permissions: Your user should have sufficient permissions (Global Account Admin, Directory Admin, Subaccount Admin) to view users in the target scopes.
  • Windows PowerShell: The script example uses PowerShell, but similar logic can be implemented in Bash or Python.
  • Working Directory: Place your files in `C:\BTP` (or another folder of your choice).

Folder Structure

Suggested folder contents:

C:\BTP\btp.exe *(SAP BTP CLI executable)*
C:\BTP\btp-all-users-with-origins.ps1 *(PowerShell script for extraction)*

 

PowerShell Script Overview

The script will:
- List all directories and subaccounts in your global account.
- For each subaccount, fetch all users and their identity provider origins.
- Aggregate results into a CSV file for easy analysis and reporting.

After logging in, Open Powershell Window and again change the folder to C:\BTP and run the PowerShell script with the following command: .\btp-all-users-with-origins.ps1

Conclusion

Automating the extraction of all users (with IdP origins) from SAP BTP‚Äôs global landscape is made possible via the btp CLI and PowerShell scripting. This approach helps admins map, reconcile, and audit user access efficiently, overcoming cockpit UI limitations.

Feel free to adapt or extend the script for additional reporting, periodic scheduled runs, or integration with ITSM tools.

Code for PowerShell Script:

 

##-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# PowerShell Script: btp-all-users-with-origins.ps1
#
# This script fetches all subaccounts, extracts all IDP origin keys,
# and then fetches all users from each subaccount for each origin key
# using the IDP via "--of-idp <originKey>".
# The user details are saved to all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv.

# Output CSV header (includes IDP origin)
"subaccount_guid,subaccount_name,originKey,userUUID,email,roles,lastLogin" | Out-File -Encoding UTF8 all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv

# Step 1: List all subaccounts and extract subaccount GUIDs and names
Write-Host "Fetching subaccounts..."
.\btp list accounts/subaccount > subaccounts.txt

$subaccounts = @()
$subLines = Get-Content subaccounts.txt | Select-Object -Skip 4
foreach ($line in $subLines) {
if ($line.Trim() -eq "") { continue }
if ($line -match '^([a-f0-9\-]{36})\s+(.+)$') {
$subaccounts += @{
guid = $matches[1]
name = $matches[2]
}
}
}

# Step 2: Gather all IDP origin keys from all subaccounts (combine)
$idpOriginSet = @{}

foreach ($subaccount in $subaccounts) {
Write-Host "Fetching IDP trusts for: $($subaccount.name) ($($subaccount.guid))..."
.\btp list security/trust --subaccount $($subaccount.guid) > idp_trusts.txt

$trustLines = Get-Content idp_trusts.txt | Select-Object -Skip 1
foreach ($trust in $trustLines) {
$trust = $trust.Trim()
if ($trust -match '(?<OriginKey>([a-zA-Z0-9\.\-]+|sap\.default))\s+(Active|Inactive)$') {
$originKey = $matches['OriginKey']
if ($originKey) { $idpOriginSet[$originKey] = $true }
}
}
}
$idpOriginList = $idpOriginSet.Keys

Write-Host "Collected IDP origin keys:"
$idpOriginList | ForEach-Object { Write-Host $_ }

# Step 3: For each subaccount and each origin key, get users with origin filtering
foreach ($subaccount in $subaccounts) {
foreach ($originKey in $idpOriginList) {
Write-Host "Fetching users for subaccount: $($subaccount.name) ($($subaccount.guid)) with origin: $originKey..."
.\btp list security/user --subaccount $($subaccount.guid) --of-idp $originKey > users.txt

$userLines = Get-Content users.txt | Where-Object {
($_ -match '\S') -and
($_ -notmatch 'username') -and
($_ -notmatch '^OK$') -and
($_ -notmatch '^No users found')
}

foreach ($userline in $userLines) {
$email = $userline.Trim()
if ($email -eq "") { continue }

# Get user details
$userDetails = .\btp get security/user $email --subaccount $($subaccount.guid) 2>&1

# Extract UUID (user ID)
$userIdLine = $userDetails | Where-Object { $_ -match '^id:' }
$userUUID = if ($userIdLine) { $userIdLine -replace '^id:\s*', '' } else { "" }

# Extract Role Collections
$roleLines = $userDetails | Select-String -Pattern '^ - '
$roles = if ($roleLines) { ($roleLines | ForEach-Object { $_.ToString().Trim() }) -join ';' } else { "" }

# Extract Last Login
$loginLine = $userDetails | Where-Object { $_ -match '^Last Login:' }
$lastLogin = if ($loginLine) { $loginLine -replace '^Last Login:\s*', '' } else { "N/A" }

"$($subaccount.guid),$($subaccount.name),$originKey,$userUUID,$email,$roles,$lastLogin" | Out-File -Append -Encoding UTF8 all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv
}
}
}

Write-Host "DONE! Output saved to all_users_detailed_with_origins.csv"

##-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

entry.title: Good to know: Full System Info Dump (FSID) vs Runtime Dump (RTE) in context of SAP HANA database
entry.content:
• Why was this blog post created?
  • Where can I find the most important information about the FSID and RTE?
  • How to collect both FSID and RTE together to get the most detailed trace for complete investigation?
  • What is the conclusion?
  • Other article
  • Do you have further questions?
  • Contribution

last updated: 2026-01-02

Why was this blog post created?

There is a lot of confusion about the different types of trace files. When troubleshooting a problem, in many case the wrong trace file is collected.

It is important to be aware and understand that different trace types can be collected from the SAP HANA database and that they are suitable for identifying different problems. In some cases only Full System Info Dump (FSID) is needed, while in other cases Runtime Dump (RTE) is needed. In special cases, both may be needed.

Where can I find the most important information about the FSID and RTE?

SAP Community Article: Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?

  • section Full System Info Dump (FSID)
  • section Runtime Dump (RTE)
 Full System Info Dump (FSID)Runtime Dump (RTE)
Issue timeHappened in the past.Happens in real time.
When to use?Root Cause Analysis (RCA)Real-Time Analysis (RTA)
When to collect?Anytime (but must include the time when the problem occurred, e.g. collected last 7 days of trace while issue occurred 3 days ago).Real time, when the issue occurs actually.
ExamplesSystem crash, oom - out of memory issue, etc.High CPU, slow system, slow execution, unresponsive or hung system, blocked transaction, general performance issue, etc.
How to analyze?Mainly manual trace checking/reviewing but there are tools also.

2498739 - How-To: Analyzing Runtime Dumps with SAP HANA Dump Analyzer

How to collect both FSID and RTE together to get the most detailed trace for complete investigation?

The following scenario explains the proper order of the trace collection activity.

  1. Collecting RTE files (during the issue exists, while the system slow, unresponsive, hung or high CPU utilization , etc. observed).
  2. Restart the system manually (to bring the system back to normal/stable/working state) or wait until it performs well again (issue solved on its own, e.g. cause of the performance issue solved, long running execution finally finished, CPU usage dropped).
  3. Collecting FSID files (after the system restarted successfully or performance issue solved on its own and the system is up and running normally again).

What is the conclusion?

While issue reported to SAP it is a good practice to upload the relevant traces right away. This will speed up the case handling process.

Other article

‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?
‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find information about the available tools for SAP HANA (all types of use)?

Do you have further questions?

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
Q&A link for SAP HANA: https://answers.sap.com/tags/73554900100700000996 

Contribution

If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

Release DateDescription
2026.01.02First/initial Release of the SAP Blog Post documentation (Technical Article).

entry.title: Re: MRP material substitution
entry.content:
Oh my bad - yes Quota arrangement alone cannot split demand between different materials. To achieve the gradual transition, you need either interchangeability setup, alternative BOMs, material determination, or a custom enhancement. Since SAP standard doesn‚Äôt directly support quota splitting across different materials, please clarify the following:

  • Are the two part numbers interchangeable in BOMs or production?
  • Is the requirement to split procurement (MRP planned orders) or sales orders?
  • Would the business accept a dummy planning material approach, or is a custom enhancement acceptable?

entry.title: 2026: Strange promt on first login to community.sap.com - SAP (universal?) ID.
entry.content:
Note: Today, when I logged in to community.sap.com (with my SAP (universal?) ID), I was promted to
- register a new SAP (universal?) ID
or

entry.title: Re: Purchasing BOM
entry.content:
There‚Äôs no standard ‚Äúconnect items‚Äù function in SAP POs. The closest standard solutions are purchasing BOMs (so ordering one material automatically brings in the other) or subcontracting POs (if the second item is a component). Otherwise, you‚Äôll need either manual addition or a custom enhancement to enforce the link. Also, please clarify the following:

  • Is the second item always procured together with the first, or only sometimes?
  • Is the second item consumed with the first (like a component), or just shipped together?
  • Should the second item be a separate PO line (with its own price/quantity), or can it be modeled as a component?
  • Is this requirement vendor‚Äëspecific or global across all POs?

entry.title: Re: How to delete requirement template in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hello Customer,

I understand you are looking to delete a requirement template, and I am here to assist you with the necessary steps.
To proceed, please follow these instructions:

1. Click on the `...` menu associated with the template you wish to delete.  
2. Select the `set to obsolete` option.  
3. Navigate to the filter settings and add the state,
4. Select "obsolete" to filter out the template.  
5. Once the template is displayed, select it and click on the `Delete` button to remove it.

Best regards,
Ellie

entry.title: Re: Unable to link p-user with s-user because they both h...
entry.content:
An email that is already a part of another SAP Universal ID account can't be added to another one and SAP Universal IDs cannot be merged. Please first remove the relevant email address from the existing SAP Universal ID or delete the entire duplicate Universal ID (KBA 3619621) 

For additional information, you may find the following Knowledge Base Articles helpful:
3582276 - Can Universal IDs (UID) be merged?
2882908 - How to add an additional user or e-mail address to the SAP Universal ID (UID) 

For any subsequent issues you may face, log a support case under XX-SER-UID through Get Support, and the support team will help resolve them.

Virtual

February 5, 2026

Agenda

Dear Valued Customer,

We are excited to invite you to the SAP MaxAttention Innovation Workshop on the topic ‚ÄúSustainability‚Äù which will be held virtually on February 5, 2026. You can find the detailed agenda for the workshop here.

The workshop will begin with a leadership kick-off that frames SAP‚Äôs vision for Sustainability and its relevance in today‚Äôs cloud transformation strategies.

Next, you will receive an overview of SAP‚Äôs Sustainability strategy and solution portfolio, including key goals and customer value drivers, followed by practical guidance on adoption options and how to make the most of your Sustainability license to accelerate outcomes.

We will then dive into the latest capabilities and roadmap for Sustainability Control Tower (SCT), showcasing how to enable end-to-end visibility and performance management across your sustainability KPIs.

The workshop continues with Sustainability Footprint Management (SFM), covering product and corporate footprint analysis, supplier engagement, and upcoming innovations to support accurate, auditable reporting.

We will also explore Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), including recent updates and roadmap highlights that help organizations ensure compliance, and drive continuous improvement.

Finally, the workshop will present the comprehensive SAP MaxAttention services portfolio for Sustainability, designed to support customers with adoption planning, migration safeguarding, and ongoing value realization. The session will also highlight how customers can leverage the SAP MaxAttention methodology to develop their custom Sustainability solutions in collaboration with the SAP Custom Innovation Services organization.

Our Workshops

These sessions and workshop series focus on a specific topic and the purpose is to enable our customers to understand the product portfolio and innovative technologies of SAP in order to drive adoption and consumption. As specifically now, it is more important than ever to help companies to be successful and to respond to changing markets by transforming into intelligent enterprises in the experience economy.

Your feedback

entry.title: Re: How to Access SAP Cloud Logging Service Dashboards Using IAS SAML Authentication
entry.content:
Hello @Umezuki and SAP Cloud Logging users,

Especially when introducing SAML authentication to existing Cloud Logging instances, we recommend to setup all the SAP IAS prerequisites first and only then update your CLS instance with the SAML parameters (Step 2 after 5). This ensures to not lose access temporarily (e.g. due to missing permissions).

Note that you could also use request signing instead of defining the SSO Endpoint and Single Logout endpoint (in Step 3). Especially when managing multiple CLS instances this will be a benefit since those endpoints would need to be repeated for every instance (see documentation). 

Thanks for this blog post and kind regards,

SAP Cloud Logging service team

entry.title: Re: Connecting BTP/BDC
entry.content:
This is a complex setup because SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) introduces a new "SAP Managed" layer (Foundation Services) on top of the standard SAP Datasphere connectivity.

Connecting your S/4HANA and BW/4HANA systems has two distinct paths: one for the standard Datasphere (Custom Data Products) and one for the BDC Foundation Services (SAP Managed Data Products).

First, BTP & Cloud Connector

The "tunnel" between your on-premise landscape and the SAP BTP/BDC tenant must be established.

  1. SAP Cloud Connector (SCC): This is mandatory.

    • Action: Install the Cloud Connector in your on-premise.
    • Configuration: Connect it to the Subaccount associated with your SAP Datasphere/BDC tenant.
    • Mapping: You must map the internal hostnames and ports of your S/4HANA and BW/4HANA systems to virtual hostnames.
    • Resources: Grant access to necessary resources

  2. Data Provisioning Agent (DP Agent):

    • Required for: Real-time replication and remote tables in SAP Datasphere (Custom Data Products).
    • Action: Install the DP Agent on a server close to your source systems.
    • Configuration: Connect the Agent to SAP Datasphere (via System > Configuration > Data Integration). Enable the necessary adapters (e.g., HANAAdapter, ABAPAdapter).

Second, connecting S/4HANA to SAP BDC

There are two "pipes" you need to configure for S/4HANA in a BDC environment.

Path A: The "BDC Push" (For SAP-Managed Data Products)

This connection allows S/4HANA to "push" data into the BDC Foundation Services to fuel the pre-packaged "Insight Apps" (e.g., Working Capital Management). This uses the ABAP Push Replication Service (APRS).

  • Prerequisite: S/4HANA 2021 or higher.
  • Step 1: Install Technical Notes
    • Apply SAP Note 3500131 (ABAP Data Integration for SAP Business Data Cloud) to your S/4HANA system. This installs the push framework.
  • Step 2: Inbound Communication (S/4HANA)
    • Create a Technical User in S/4HANA.
    • Assign the specific role SAP_BDC_REMOTE (provided via note 3499606) to this user. This allows BDC to call into S/4HANA to trigger loads.
  • Step 3: Outbound Communication (S/4HANA to BDC)
    • Certificates: Use transaction STRUST to create a PSE (Personal Security Environment) and generate a client certificate. Upload this certificate to the BDC/BTP environment (often handled via the BDC Cockpit or BTP destination service).
    • RFC Destination: Create an RFC destination (Type G or H) in S/4HANA pointing to the BDC Foundation Service endpoint (via Cloud Connector).
    • Register: Register this outbound communication in S/4HANA so the APRS knows where to push the data.
  • Step 4: Monitoring
    • Use transaction DHADM in S/4HANA to monitor the push framework and load status.

Path B: The "Datasphere Pull" (For Custom Data Products) not BDC way

This allows you to build your own models in Datasphere by pulling tables/views from S/4HANA.

  • Action: Log into SAP Datasphere.
  • Connection: Go to Connections > Create. Select SAP S/4HANA On-Premise.
  • Configuration:
    • Select Use Cloud Connector.
    • Enter the Virtual Host and Port you defined in Phase 1.
    • Enter the SAP User/Password (Communication User) created in S/4HANA.
    • Select the Data Provisioning Agent you registered.
  • Result: You can now use "Remote Tables" and "Replication Flows" to ingest Z-tables or CDS views.

 

Connecting BW/4HANA to SAP BDC

If you are in BW modernization, SAP recommends the "Shift" approach using the Data Product Generator. Note that this generally requires your BW system to be in the Private Cloud Edition (PCE) environment to fully integrate with the BDC Foundation Services

Path A: The Data Product Generator (For BW Modernization)

This pushes BW InfoProviders (ADSOs, CompositeProviders) directly into the BDC Object Store (Data Lake Files).

  • Prerequisite: BW/4HANA 2021 SP04+ or BW 7.5 SP24+ (on HANA).
  • Configuration (SAP Note 3590400):
    • You must run a task list in BW (transaction STC01) to configure the connection to the BDC Object Store.
    • This involves configuring an OAuth Client in Datasphere and mapping it in BW so BW can authenticate against the BDC storage.
  • Execution:
    • BW/4HANA: Go to the BW Cockpit (Transaction BW4WEB). Look for the "Data Product Generator" tile.
    • BW 7.5: Use transaction RSDPS.
    • Create a Data Subscription. Select your InfoProvider (e.g., a CompositeProvider).
    • Activate: This triggers the push of data into a "Local Table" in the BW Inbound Space of SAP Datasphere.

Path B: The "Model Transfer" (For Metadata Federation) not BDC way

If you want to move BW metadata (semantics) into Datasphere:

  • Tool: Use the SAP BW/4HANA Model Transfer.
  • Action: In Datasphere, use "Semantic Onboarding" or "Import Model".
  • Connectivity: Relies on the Cloud Connector (RFC) connection established in Phase 1.

In your scenario, strictly separate the "Management Plane" (BDC Cockpit/Foundation Services) traffic from the "Data Plane" (Datasphere/DP Agent) traffic. Path A relies on the new ABAP Push/HTTPs protocols, while DP Agent relies on established JDBC/RFC tunnels (Path B above) which is like not using BDC fully.

entry.title: Story SSO - troubleshooting Points
entry.content:
A very common scenario: users can log on to SuccessFactors without any problem, but fail to open a Story report. This is caused by failure of SF->Story SSO. 

There are quite a few possible reasons for this. KBA 2912865 ‚Äì [Main KBA] Unable to access Story reports in SuccessFactors already covers most of them in detail. This post is meant as a simpler and add‚Äëon to that KBA, focusing on the checks I do in projects.

1. Use Upgrade Center to activate Story in IAS. The out of box setup is reliable and straigtforward. Avoid customizing too much. 

2. Make sure you use the correct URL. If you‚Äôre using an IAS ‚Äúbackdoor‚Äù URL, make sure you‚Äôre using the new accounts.cloud.sap domain and not the legacy one.

Correct Domain

https://iastenant88.accounts.cloud.sap/saml2/idp/sso?sp=https://www.successfactors.com/ sftenant88&idp=https:// iastenant88.accounts.ondemand.com

Legacy domain (Do not use)

https://iastenant88.accounts.ondemand.com/saml2/idp/sso?sp=https://www.successfactors.com/ sftenant88&idp=https:// iastenant88.accounts.ondemand.com

It is because IAS has undergone common super domain migration. The legacy domain URL will not work for Story SSO.

3. Make sure your browser is set up correctly. Refer to KBA 3039244 - Unable to access Story Reports due to Browser Settings - MS Edge & Google Chrome

4. Make sure SF UDF PERSON_GUID is maintained and replicated to IAS user profile Custom Attribute 1 successfully. This field is configured as Subject Name Identifier as per standard.

5. Make sure the user trying to access Story has the right permission and successfully replicated to Story. Check IPS Job Execution Details.

6. If you as a consultant can access Story successfully, but end users still can‚Äôt access it even with correct browser settings, there‚Äôs a chance the corporate network is blocking SF/Story domains. In that case, ask the customer‚Äôs network team to whitelist SF/Story domains. 

Above 7 points are typically what I checked during implementation when Story SSO is not working. It covers majority of root causes.

entry.title: Re: SAP Personas - table view on mobile
entry.content:
Table on classic webgui application wasn't designed to be used with mobile device, I suppose. 
The number of visible rows in some applications depends on available height of the window and user area. 

In your case, the best option is to play around with "resize()" Scripting API and increase the height of window and user area:

  1. Create onLoad event script for screen where Table is visible:  
    session.findById("wnd[0]").resize(500, 1000, 500, 1000);
  2. Play around with width and height parameters

Not sure how much more visible rows is possible to get but I was able to get 6-8 rows instead of 3 on VA02 app Sales TAB for iPhone.

The only problem here is that if you will increase Height in such way, you will have some extra empty space below. But this seems good trade off.

Best Regards!

entry.title: SHA 256 & AES 128 conversion issue
entry.content:
Hi All, Please help in this matter.

We are accessing external API via PI/PO in abap program. Please find attached below code for your reference.

TRY.
    CALL METHOD lo_client_proxy->sios_get_token_cnr
      EXPORTING
        output = ls_request " Outbound data (request)
      IMPORTING
        input  = ls_response. " Inbound data (response)

    COMMIT WORK. " Essential for sending the message via XI runtime

* 4. PROCESS the response DATA
    WRITE: / 'Message sent successfully'.

entry.title: Re: Custom field has no value help in some screens but ha...
entry.content:
Dear @kostadin_terziev,

What you‚Äôre seeing is a UI-technology limitation, not an issue with your CDS value help

  • Post General Journal Entries is a SAPUI5/Fiori app. For key-user custom fields, SAPUI5 consumes the OData/CDS value help annotations so the value help dialog can be rendered
  • FB60/FB70 even when started from the launchpad are classic transaction apps SAP GUI. Those screens use the SAP GUI F4/search help mechanism, and they do not consume the CDS/OData value help metadata that your Code List based on CDS View field relies on. Result the field can be shown, but the value help popup is not triggered/available. SAP explicitly documents this as a limitation for these apps

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3555532

Summary:

In Public Cloud you can‚Äôt make classic SAP GUI transactions behave like SAPUI5 for key-user CDS-based value helps. So same behavior across all screens is only achievable by standardizing on screens that support the Fiori extensibility/value help framework

Recommended approach:

  • For supplier invoices use Manage Supplier Invoices (F0859) instead of FB60
  • For mass/automated creation use Import Supplier Invoices (F3041) or posting APIs also suggested by SAP

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F0859')/S35

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F3041')/S35

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Implementation Guide: Integrating the UI5 Spreadsheet Importer in a FIORI Application
entry.content:
1.0 Introduction to the UI5 Spreadsheet Importer

The Spreadsheet Importer offers several strategic advantages that make it an invaluable tool for modern FIORI development:

  • Seamless Data Integration: It allows applications to read and process Excel files directly on the front end, eliminating cumbersome manual data entry and reducing the risk of errors. A key benefit is its independence from the specific backend OData service implementation, making it compatible with both Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) scenarios.
  • Out-of-the-Box Functionality: The component supports standard spreadsheet formats (.xls and .xlsx) and utilizes the robust SheetJS library to parse file data within the browser. This avoids sending large binary files to the backend. It automatically converts spreadsheet data into the required OData format for seamless communication with your SAP system.
  • Productivity Improvements: With an intuitive interface and straightforward configuration, the component requires minimal coding effort from developers. It supports every type of OData service (SEGW, RAP, and CAP), accelerating development cycles and improving the efficiency of business processes.
  • Community and Security: As a well-regarded open-source tool, the Spreadsheet Importer benefits from strong community support on GitHub, ensuring it is well-documented and continuously improved. It maintains high security standards with no known vulnerabilities reported in recent audits.
  • Proven Track Record: The component has been successfully adopted by numerous SAP developers across the ecosystem. Its reliability is underscored by its implementation as an extension in a standard SAP banking application, proving its scalability for mission-critical enterprise environments.

Before beginning implementation, it is essential to understand the specific licensing and versioning requirements associated with this component.

2.0 Critical Prerequisites: Licensing and Version Control

Adhering to the correct licensing and versioning requirements is a critical prerequisite for any implementation. This ensures full compliance with open-source software policies and guarantees the long-term stability and supportability of your application.

The component is available under two distinct licensing models, and it is mandatory to use the approved version.

Version

Licensing and Usage Details

Version 1.x (e.g., 1.7.4)

Licensed under Apache 2.0. This is the free-of-charge Community Edition. 

Version 2.0.0 and above

Requires a commercial license.

Mandatory Version

To ensure consistency and compliance across all projects, a specific version has been mandated for all development.

The required and approved version for all implementations we have used in this article - 1.7.4.

With these prerequisites established, we can proceed with the technical steps required for integration.

3.0 Step-by-Step Implementation Workflow

Integrating the Spreadsheet Importer into a FIORI Element application involves five core steps. This workflow covers modifications to the UI manifest, the implementation of controller logic, and the necessary configurations for the project's dependencies and build scripts.

3.1 Step 1: Add the Custom "Excel Upload" Action

The first step is to add a custom action button to the List Report page. This is accomplished by extending the view controller within the application's manifest.json file.

Add the following "extends" block to your manifest.json:

"extends": {
  "extensions": {
    "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
      "sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ListReport.view.ListReport": {
        "controllerName": "<yournamespace>.doerategrp.ext.controller.ListReportExt",
        "sap.ui.generic.app": {
          "rateGroupSet": {
            "EntitySet": "rateGroupSet",
            "Actions": {
              "excelUpload": {
                "id": "excelUploadButton",
                "text": "Excel Upload",
                "press": "openSpreadsheetUpload",
                "requiresSelection": false
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

This configuration achieves the following:

  • "controllerName": Specifies the custom controller extension file that will contain the button's logic.
  • "id": "excelUploadButton": Assigns a unique ID to the new button control.
  • "text": "Excel Upload": Sets the display text for the button on the UI.
  • "press": "openSpreadsheetUpload": Defines the event handler function that will be called when the user clicks the button.

Pro-Tip: The controllerName (com.deere.doerategrp.ext.controller.ListReportExt) and the EntitySet key (rateGroupSet) are specific to this example. You must update these values to match your project's namespace and the target OData EntitySet for the table you are extending.

3.2 Step 2: Configure the Controller Extension (ListReportExt.controller.js)

Next, you must implement the openSpreadsheetUpload event handler defined in the manifest.json. This function will reside in your custom controller extension file, ListReportExt.controller.js.

Use the following code to implement the function. It is important to only use the openSpreadsheetUpload function as provided; other methods mentioned in the source documentation, such as attachChangeBeforeCreate and attachUploadButtonPress, may not be usable and should be ignored.

sap.ui.define(["sap/m/MessageToast"], function (MessageToast) {
    'use strict';

    return {
        openSpreadsheetUpload: async function (oEvent) {
            MessageToast.show("Spreadsheet upload initiated.");
            this.getView().setBusyIndicatorDelay(0);
            this.getView().setBusy(true);
            this.spreadsheetUpload = await this.getView()
                .getController()
                .getOwnerComponent()
                .createComponent({
                    usage: "spreadsheetImporter",
                    async: true,
                    componentData: {
                        context: this,
                        columns: ['shippingPoint', 'destRegion', 'matFrtGroup', 'shippingType', 'validFrom', 'validTo', 'rateGroups'],
                        mandatoryFields: ['shippingPoint', 'destRegion', 'matFrtGroup', 'shippingType', 'validFrom'],
                        showBackendErrorMessages: true,
                        continueOnError: true,
                        useTableSelector: false,
                        addArrayToMessages: true,
                        strict: true,
                        tableId: "<yournamespace>.doerategrp::sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ListReport.view.ListReport::rateGroupSet--responsiveTable",
                        sampleData: [{
                            shippingPoint: 'HX1C',
                            destRegion: 'MD',
                            matFrtGroup: 'OMFR0005',
                            shippingType: '10',
                            validFrom: '9999-12-31',
                            validTo: '9999-12-31',
                            rateGroups: 'RT002'
                        }]
                    },
                });
            
            await this.spreadsheetUpload.triggerInitContext();
            
            this.spreadsheetUpload.openSpreadsheetUploadDialog();
            this.getView().setBusy(false);
        }
    };
});

The componentData object is used to configure the importer's behavior. Key parameters include:

  • columns: An array of strings defining the OData property names that correspond to the columns in the spreadsheet.
  • mandatoryFields: An array of strings specifying which columns must contain data for a row to be considered valid.
  • tableId: The full ID of the target table in the List Report where the data will be inserted. You can find this ID by inspecting the table element in your browser's developer tools. It must be the complete, stable ID for the target sap.m.Table or sap.ui.table.Table.
  • sampleData: Provides a sample data row that can be used to generate a downloadable template for users.

3.3 Step 3: Define Component Dependencies in manifest.json

The application manifest must be updated to declare its dependency on the Spreadsheet Importer component. This allows the UI5 framework to locate and load the component's resources.

Add the following componentUsages and resourceRoots configurations to your manifest.json:

"componentUsages": {
  "spreadsheetImporter": {
    "name": "cc.spreadsheetimporter.v1_7_4"
  }
},
"resourceRoots": {
  "cc.spreadsheetimporter.v1_7_4": "./thirdparty/customcontrol/spreadsheetimporter/v1_7_4"
},

The key spreadsheetImporter is a local alias defined for this component's usage. This alias is what you will use to reference the component within your application's controller code. The resourceRoots path shown here is configured for local development and testing within SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). This path will be adjusted for deployment to an on-premise system, as detailed later in this guide.

3.4 Step 4: Update Project Dependencies in package.json

To enable local development, testing, and builds, the Spreadsheet Importer component must be added as a dependency in the project's package.json file.

Add the following line to the dependencies section of your package.json:

// In your package.json, add the following to "dependencies":
"ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter": "^1.7.4"

3.5 Step 5: Configure the Build Script

The final configuration step is to modify the build script in package.json to ensure that all dependencies, including the custom component, are correctly processed during the build.

Add the --all flag to the "build" script command:

"build": "ui5 build --config=ui5.yaml --all --clean-dest --dest dist",

With the application now fully configured for local development and testing, the next crucial phase is to prepare it for deployment to a production-like on-premise environment, which follows a specific, centralized strategy.

4.0 On-Premise Deployment Strategy

For on-premise landscapes, a centralized deployment model for the Spreadsheet Importer component is mandatory. This model leverages a single, pre-existing instance of the component that has been deployed centrally as a BSP application. This simplifies individual application deployments, as you only need to reference this central component rather than deploying it with every application.

4.1 Understanding the resourceRoots Path for Deployed Applications

The resourceRoots path in the manifest.json file is environment-specific. The path used for local development in BAS is different from the one required for a deployed application running on the FIORI Launchpad.

Environment

resourceRoots Path in manifest.json

BAS / Local Development

"./thirdparty/customcontrol/spreadsheetimporter/v1_7_4"

On-Premise Deployment

"./thirdparty/customcontrol/spreadsheetimporter/v1_7_4"

The path for the deployed application points to a centrally available BSP application named ZVA0_EXL_UPD. This BSP application already contains the approved version 1.7.4 of the Spreadsheet Importer component, making it available to all other FIORI applications on the same system.

4.2 Recommended Deployment Configuration for Consistency

To avoid manually changing the resourceRoots path in manifest.json before each deployment, the recommended best practice is to update the build configuration. By excluding certain development-only files from the deployment package, you can maintain a single, consistent manifest.json for both local and deployed environments.

Update your ui5-deploy.yaml file to exclude TypeScript (.ts, .ts.map) and JavaScript map (.js.map) files from the deployment artifact.

- name: deploy-to-abap
  afterTask: generateCachebusterInfo
  configuration:
    target:
      # ... target system details
    app:
      # ... application details
    exclude:
      - /test/
      - .*\.ts
      - .*\.ts.map
      - .*\.js.map

This approach is critical for robust development and deployment pipelines, as it eliminates the need for error-prone manual modifications to the manifest.json file between environments. The local resourceRoots path is automatically ignored during deployment, and the relative path to the central BSP is correctly resolved when the application runs on the FIORI Launchpad.

5.0 Troubleshooting and Known Issues

While the integration process is generally straightforward, developers should be aware of a known issue that may occur during the deployment from SAP Business Application Studio to an on-premise system.

When deploying an application that uses the Spreadsheet Importer component, the deployment process in BAS may report a failure. However, in most cases, the BSP application is still created or updated successfully in the backend ABAP system. This behavior is a known open issue that has been reported to SAP.

For more details on this issue, please refer to the SAP Community discussion: Error when deploying UI5 app (sapui5 library/component used in application)

If you encounter this error, verify the status of the BSP application directly in the backend system before attempting to redeploy.

6.0 Final Validation

The final step is to verify that the Spreadsheet Importer component is fully functional in the target environment.

After a successful deployment, launch your application from the SAP FIORI Launchpad. You should see the "Excel Upload" button on the List Report page. Clicking this button should open the spreadsheet import dialog, confirming that the integration was successful and is ready for users to begin the data import process.

7.0 Appendix: Key Resources

For further information, detailed documentation, and community support, please refer to the following resources:

  • Official GitHub Repository: ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter
  • Live Demo Launchpad: Spreadsheet Importer Live Demo
  • NPM Package: ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter
  • Yeoman Generator: generator-ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter
  • Official Documentation: Spreadsheet Importer Docs
  • Example Applications: Code Samples
  • wdi5 Tests: Test Examples

entry.title: Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Do you want to see more content like this? Please live a Kudos!

Introduction

Resource Orchestration is a cloud-based scheduling tool in SAP Digital Manufacturing that helps production supervisors stay in control of shop floor execution. It provides a clear overview of operations, resource workloads, and current production status, while automatically balancing work across available resources.

With the Real-Time Monitor, supervisors can quickly respond to changes in production, follow operation schedules and order execution as they happen, identify delays or issues early, and track order progress throughout the shift. This gives supervisors the visibility and flexibility needed to keep production running smoothly and on plan.

Learn below how a Production Supervisor can leverage Resource Orchestration Real-Time Monitor for enhanced scheduling and monitoring in 6 simple steps.

Learn more at Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Step 1: Starting the Day with Real-Time Visibility

At the start of his day, the production supervisor, opens the Real-Time Monitoring View in SAP Digital Manufacturing.
This view gives him a live picture of what is happening on the shop floor right now.

From a single screen, Eliam can see:

  • Which operations are running, completed, or waiting

  • The current progress of each order

  • The status of individual shop floor controls (SFCs)

This helps him understand the current situation before taking any action.

Step 2: Dispatching Pending Operations

As the production supervisor reviews the list, he notices that some operations are still waiting to be dispatched.
If these stay unassigned, production could slow down.

He selects the pending operations and assigns them to available resources that are ready to work.
With just a few actions, the operations are dispatched and execution continues without interruption.

Step 3: Preventing Backlogs Before They Happen

Next, the production supervisor focuses on operations that are close to falling behind plan.

He opens the details of these operations and checks:

  • The related SFCs

  • Their current execution status

  • Where time is being spent

Based on this information, production supervisor adjusts the plan to keep work moving forward and avoid creating a backlog.

Learn more at Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Step 4: Increasing Throughput by Adjusting Labor

To further speed things up, the production supervisor checks the current labor shift plan.

He sees that additional capacity is needed later in the day.
Instead of waiting for delays to occur, he adds more workers to the next shift.

This increases throughput and keeps production aligned with demand.

Step 5: Ensuring the Right Skills Are in Place

Production supervisor then reviews workforce information to make sure execution matches the plan.

He checks:

  • Clock-in and attendance status

  • Worker skills

  • Current assignments

  • Time log entries

This ensures that each operation is performed by someone with the right skills at the right time.

Step 6: Staying in Control Throughout the Shift

Throughout the day, production supervisor keeps the Real-Time Monitoring View open.

As conditions change, he can:

  • Track order progress as it happens

  • Spot delays early

  • Adjust resources or labor immediately

This allows him to stay in control of shop floor execution and keep production running smoothly.

Summary

With Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing, supervisors can:

  • See what is happening on the shop floor right now

  • Act immediately when issues appear

  • Adjust resources and labor without delay

  • Keep production on track throughout the shift

This step-by-step flow shows how supervisors can move from visibility to action, all within a single view.

Learn more at Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Do you want to see more content like this? Please live a Kudos!

If you have any questions, please check SAP Community Q&A Area, or comment down below.

Thanks,
Manoel Costa

entry.title: Re: Personas flavor across create, change, display
entry.content:
Hi, 

All SAP Screen Personas changes saved for combination of Transaction/Program/ScreenNumber and Control ID. 
If all this is similar between transactions then there is way to copy one prepared Flavor to other transactions (application IDs) link.

Looking to FMZ1, FMZ2 and FMZ3, I see that Details screen looks the same and Flavors can be copied with no issues to apply changes. 

The only problem you could experience is that Toolbar has different set of buttons between transactions and also Initial screen is different (there are different fields on FMZ1 comparing to ...2/3).

So maybe the way is to create Flavor for FMZ2 and then to copy it to FMZ1 and FMZ2. Then update Initial Screen of FMZ1.

Since SP20 there is an option to copy Flavor to Flavor (if you have to update Flavor, then you can copy it to already existing). However in case described above, you will have to redo chances of initials screen of FMZ1 again.

Best Regards!

entry.title: Re: S/4 Hana 2025 Compatibility with DMIS 2018 SP07

Hello, 

 

If your SLT system is on DMIS 2018 SP07, using source system with S/4HANA 2025 is not compatible as you can see in note below:

0003130804 - Release Information SLT - DMIS 2018 SP07
The latest S/4HANA that can be used with DMIS 2018 SP07 is S/4HANA 2023.

 

Best Regards, 

SAP Support

entry.content: Hi @William_Yu1. I know this is a old post, but I'm facing the same problem that Charles had. But, I'm already using the optimized story. Is there another workaround?
